author: BatMeckley
content: I would say it’s not one or the other. Like, I might do some big timing moves first, just to have the vocal 80% of the way there. I’m talking actually nudging things around, not stretching. Then I’ll consolidate and drop into Melodyne. In Melodyne I’ll turn the whole thing and also really pay attention to the timing. At this stage it’s a lot more stretching and/or compressing notes, or more importantly PARTS of words. Like I’ll separate the consonant, and time compress that and bring up the volume so ccchhhhhhhhair becomes CHaaaaiiirrrr. (If that makes any sense). Then back into ProTools. Double check for any weirdness, comp back in the untuned bits you can get away with if you want. Then I’ll do a final cleaning up of group Esses, do my little what I call Swedish time stretching technique, REALLY pocket and polish the vocals. Then I send it off to the label who needed it yesterday but somehow don’t get back to me for 6 months.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I worked with a band at the very beginning that was a three piece with VERY specific rules. 

1) all songs had to be under 2:45
2) guitars and vocals could be doubled for tone, but not parts.
3) bassist sang lead, if there was a harmony the guitarist (not a gifted singer) had to sing it, if there was a third part the drummer had to sing it (couldn’t sing at all)
4) record couldn’t take more than a week to record/mix 

It was the project that convinced Luke I could be a producer; his fav record id done up to that point.

There’s a real value to putting strict limitations on your art, it often brings the most clarity and creativity. Side note: they were terrible technical musicians but just fucking AWESOME.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This is an important question, with some boring answers usually. 

1) make sure you can trust your monitoring. Having to double check your sounds all day is a huge time/vibe suck. 
2) if you’re recording real instruments, optimize your studio space for simplicity. Occam’s Razor. Have chains setup and ready to go for easy grab & go recording. 
3) you don’t need as many elements in the recording if each sound/performance is excellent on its own. 
4) Chase the joy. Some elements are nuts & bolts, but if you find the joy in each part you’re working on, that shines through performances. 
5) remember that not everything needs to be done in a day. Sometimes things take longer and that’s ok.

author: popaganda.
content: No matter what I’d be trying to build off a live performance. Vocals and guitar at the same time if possible, make sure the artist is comfortable enough to really deliver the way they did on their videos. Sometimes when artists get in the studio they get way in their heads, and then the process of doing takes and dressing up a track piece by piece can really cloud up the original energy that the fans connected with. So no matter how you eventually dress it up, the core has to be as dynamic and connective as possible.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@BatMeckley is the resident Grammy Loser on this topic, but I’ve made a decent living doing some indie and major label stuff as a vocal producer. 

Deliverables really depend on the producer you’re working with. In my experience it’s 50/50 whether they want tuned or raw, comped or all the takes- etc. 

The key things that keep me getting called are, in no particular order:

Communication. Everybody knows what to expect and what is to be expected. 

Professionalism. The room is clean, mics are up, lighting is right, session is loaded. 

Intuition. All the artistic/personal things. Making the artist feel safe enough to be dangerous, knowing how hard you can push them to get a take, knowing where the line is between their vision and yours, etc…

Sonics. I want my artists to feel expensive when they’re recording, so getting the mic and cue mix right is everything. 

Speed. A comp up by the time they’re done tracking, a quick shine to make it feel special, and a bounce for them to take with them.

Everything else is on a per session basis. I can deliver a fully mixed/tuned vocal and everything in between, so it all depends on communication ahead of time.

author: BatMeckley
content: I mostly fuck with retune speed; adjusting it slows down how hard the tune snaps to the note and it can basically reduce the “severity” of the effect. Classic mode is because when they went from 5 to 7 we all threw a fit because they fucked heavily with the “sound” of the plug in. In an effort to increase transparency they actually messed with the high end artifacts we actually dug, and were using the plugin for (on a lot of the Luke records I worked on we were using melodyne for tune and AutoTune for tone). I clearly remember sitting on the phone with Antares brass for HOURS while they tried to convince us the new version was “better” and me having to explain to them that it wasn’t and we were now traveling with rigs that had the old version because the new version just didn’t have the sound we needed. They compromised by introducing “classic” mode which was their attempt to get the sound of v5 back.

author: austenballard
content:
**RESULTS**

Null testing revealed that the tuned audio did not completely cancel out between any of the three files, even when audio was time-aligned and gain-matched. Audible signal at approx. -36 dBFS was present during playback.

Furthermore, each instance of Melodyne did not detect the audio identically. The plugin version detected Tone #1 at +48 ct, while ARA and Standalone detected it at + 50 ct. No difference was noted in the detected pitch center of Tone #2 between the three instances.

**DISCUSSION**

Testing showed Beckley, et al. (2023) to be correct in asserting that Melodyne does not behave identically between its plugin, ARA and standalone versions. Differences do not appear limited to the tuning algorithm, but indeed the detection algorithm as well. The relative subjective quality of tuning results between these versions cannot, however, be determined by the present test. Further testing and qualitative evaluation may be needed to add to the literature and determine the most preferable version of Melodyne to use for tuning purposes.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
To go further on what @Maxim said: when you stack a bunch of vocals that are all hard tuned, they're gonna phase cancel. I often detune L/R doubles of a lead by a few 10ths of a cycle (like take the left channel to 439.4hz and the right channel to 440.6hz in auto tune) to help separate them.

This is actually what a "chorus" effect is meant to do. When you actually get a bunch of great singers together to sing the same thing, their different timbres and slightly different pitches will add up to a very rich sound you can't get from stacking one tuned voice. That's what the effect called "chorus" is essentially trying to mimic with slight detune and delay.

Not sure if this is a topic we've covered much but I know @BatMeckley and @Slow Hand have thoughts

author: BatMeckley
content:
Essentially this. If you get vocals too tight they’ll start to phase cancel (and or feel mono if they’re panned.) I was just talking about this a day or two ago in the discord except in that case using melodyne. 

The technique that matt is saying is essentially a micro shift plugin or an h949. The one thing I’d say about that is you’re using a technique to fix a problem halfway that you’ve made for yourself in the first place. Remember WHY you’re stacking vocals. You want some thickness or some stereo spread. Don’t tune and time them as aggressively from the jump and you’ll be good

author: BatMeckley
content: One of my go to vocal production tricks is wiping out the consonants (and esses) from most of the vocal. A few of them goes a long way, and getting rid of most of them really tightens up a stack. (this is overdoable, and it can sound like a choir of toothless people if done wrong) but you’ll be amazed at how few consonants sounds you need in a blend.

author: bobby k
content: I will say this, on the topic of standing up for yourself -- I've seen a couple times in these threads now a general sentiment of accepting that people are gonna kick you around. It felt evident when we were riffing on sliding scale mixing rates last month and it felt evident this morning/last night in here. I'm all in on the greyhound sentiment, I've been a grafter through and through since I was in elementary school skipping homework to double up on piano practice. I once drove 7 hours to buy a Juno-60 on Craigslist and the guy didn't answer the door; I make DUMB life decisions all centered around this non-negotiable gravity towards the art. I can promise I have whatever that obsessive brain disorder thing is that we all keep riffing about (and believe the same for the grand majority here). But can we not practice a little self preservation along the way? Nobody besides your team is really gonna stick up for you; I believe that in line with the all the professional metrics there exists the opportunity/need to set  precedents on how you want to be treated. I don't think this is something that *comes* with being a great producer, I think it's something that *contributes* to someone becoming a great producer. And of course, knowing how to ask for that fairness with a kind/patient/assertive/flexible tone is critical. But if I believe something is a little crooked in the system, I'd rather not wait till I hopefully arrive a decade later on the other side of the fence to be able to do something about it. I would rather make an attempt at being heard now and see whether it makes any progress, even if it just gives some suit on an email thread something to think about. It's not for the sake of my own ego, it's for the sake of our entire breed.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The method that sounds most transparent is hand editing (no digital stretching at all). You need to line up your edits so the wave form is perfect in the middle of each note, then use an equal gain cross fade at the edit point. This gives you the most transparency because there is no algorithmic stretching happening. 

It limits very slightly your options with timing because bass wave forms are long, so lining them up perfectly means you can only move the timing the length of each waveform. It's also time consuming compared to stretching.

If you are editing a DI that is then going through significant processing (amp sims and shit), you can sometimes get away with one of the stretching algorithms. Elastic audio is ok and usable sometimes, but I prefer Ableton's complex mode over everything else I've heard.

I try to avoid time stretching artifacts on lead vocals and bass instruments more than anything else (unless it's creatively interesting of course).

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames yeahhhh. watch the questlove video on youtube where he talks about d'angelo asking him to play crazy laid back and flammy too.

my general thought on timing is: behind the beat is more groovy and laid back (vocals, percussion, bass against the kick drum, etc) and ahead is intense and anxious (especially vocals).

there are many examples of groove being behind the beat as that's something people talk about a lot. definitely dive into that concept and play with laying different elements back off the grid.

but i LOVE talking about being ahead of the beat. purists complain that a lot of modern hip hop vocals are ahead of the beat and "off time." but when it's done well it makes the tracks SO exciting. lil durk, 21 savage, gucci, etc all have this excitement in some of the songs because the vocal are ahead. 

i've heard the argument that these guys are just amateurish in their skill. that might be true, but their natural groove and cadence works. also listen to kendrick on "Family Ties" where he goes in and out of being ahead of the beat and it sounds exciting as fuck when he does.

also "Icky Thump" by White Stripes is a song with vocals that are entirely ahead of the beat. clearly it's deliberate as jack white is a rhythmic genius (and the doubles are perfect). it adds this anxiety to the whole song that is SO dope.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Wanted to share some thoughts spurred on by a recent experience on here. So a local artist has hired me to produce two of her songs. Vibe is singer-songwriter, soul, RnB.

We tracked drums, bass, and keys live in the studio OD'd to scratch tracks we cooked up together. The scratch tracks / demos were just guitar vocal and we were really relying on the players to fill out the arrangements, but we knew more would be added down the line.

All the players were incredible. Could singe your eyebrows off with technical prowess and shredtastic chops. Tracks turned out great, still working on the arrangement, but..

This project has got me thinking more about the importance of how you present a song to session musicians and the 'space' you ask them to fill in a production. As well as the changing dynamics project to project affected by a revolving cast of participants, more fleshed out demos, etc... I find this a really interesting topic. Curious if anyone in the group has any unique experiences or insights whether as a producer or a musician.

I've found that the more I flesh out demos with the artist beforehand the more bound and limited the session players we bring in are based off our decisions. This can make ODs more efficient, add a clearer direction, but can also remove the opportunity for the player to really add something special. Sometimes I don't want to be too suggestive b/c I want the players to have more of a blank canvas to work with.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Good question! 

As @cian riordan said, when you're perfectly lining up the waveform of any solid tone, you want equal gain so it doesn't give you a boost on the crossfade. This is for "correlated" signals where the waveform is lining up exactly. A bass guitar, the middle of a vocal note, a synth with a consistent waveform, etc.

When you're doing a crossfade on noise (breaths, sss's, ambience between drum hits, etc), you want equal power because these "uncorrelated" signals need a bit of boost around the crossfade for the perceived loudness to be the same.

You can check this by using a synth note or long vocal note, doing an edit to make it longer or shorter, lining up the waveforms perfectly, and doing a cross fade. You will find that equal power causes a volume bump. Equal gain will be smooth.

Do the same thing with white noise and this time equal power will be smooth, while equal gain will cause a volume dip.

author: samvalentine

@BatMeckley nailed retune and classic... Flex tune allows you to hit notes that aren't allowed in the key; higher the value, more time you're allowed on that note before it'll snap you to a note in the key. I'll keep it pretty low usually but it all depends on the vocalist. I've never really fucked with natural vibrato. Humanize is nice. Let's longer sustained notes wobble a bit even at high retune speeds. Sometimes I'll really crank it, but it does take away from the autotune effect if that's what you're going for.
One other tip is I like to flip to advanced mode and set major/minor in the bottom section (leave top drop down in chromatic). This allows you to bypass or allow certain notes that aren't in the key. So if you wanna hit that flat seven now and then, bingo

author: austenballard
content:
Test is done. Tl;dr they don't null completely. They don't even detect the same audio the same.

**INTRODUCTION**
Beckley, et al. (2023) reported differences in tuning results between the plugin and standalone versions of Melodyne. This investigator undertook a test of Melodyne plugin, ARA and standalone versions to determine whether the resulting tuned audio would null.

**METHODS**

All testing was performed at a sample rate of 48kHz and with .wav files at a bit depth of 32 bits. Tuning was tested using two 2-second square wave tones generated with FabFilter One in Logic Pro X. Tone #1 was generated at a constant pitch of C4 +50ct. Tone #2 was generated at a pitch of C4 with the following settings: Modulation Generator (MG) Frequency set to 4.033 Hz,  MG waveform set to value 0.500, and Frequency Modulation MG set to value 0.123. Each tone was printed on a separate channel as a Bounce-in-place (bip). The two bips were then joined into a single, 6-second, mono .wav file with 2 seconds of silence between the bips. The 6-second .wav file was copied onto two new channels in Logic Pro X, and dragged out of Logic Pro onto the desktop for use in Melodyne standalone.

Audio was transferred into Melodyne: one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne non-ARA, one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne ARA, and the copy of the .wav file on the desktop was loaded into Melodyne standalone. All transfers were completed using the Melodic (Standard) algorithm. 

Transferred audio was quantized to pitch C4, offset 0 ct, Pitch Modulation 0.0%, Pitch Drift 0.0%. All other settings were left at defaults; Note Assignment mode was checked to verify that Playback Type in each case was 'Tonal'. 

Resulting audio was printed and imported into three new mono channels in Logic Pro X. Null testing was performed using the phase invert feature in Logic Pro X's stock 'Gain' plugin.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m KINDA kidding, we’ve gone over this a lot on here… I much prefer the standalone workflow, but there’s a ton of people that swear by it in plugin form, it just doesn’t work for me that way, and I get different sounding results partly because of workflow and partly because we’ve verified they actually sound different (different algorithms). 

Melodyne is an incredible tool, but it’s not without its quirks. The first thing is: the correction is only as good as the detection… so it’s worth a quick run through to make sure it’s mapped the vocal take properly.  Sometimes it gets a syllable or two in the wrong octave, and rarer times it’ll get it wrong a fourth or fifth off. I’m not sure the process for correcting that in the plug in off the top of my head. Once you’ve got the detection right…

The  next step is understanding how we fundamentally sing; a note tends to have a front end or consonance, the meat of the note, and then lastly the tail. You want to separate the meat of the note out, and concentrate on tuning that. Also remember that the “blob” is just an average of the tuning info in it, meaning if your note slides from C to E, melodyne will correct that blob to D. (I hope that makes sense.)

author: BatMeckley

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've been melodyning vocals for a ten song album past couple weeks and feel like I've leveled up my chops significantly. I'm no Beckley, but browsing whats been previously shared here and trial and error has been the mechanism of growth for me.

I kinda had the note separation tool workflow down from work in other programs. I've been experimenting with the time tool and attack speed tool as well as formant shifting to mask when the tuning becomes more audible than I'd like. That's probably where I'd pinpoint the level up for me personally. That and trying to be more conscious about not relying too much on the graphical UI. Unless it's something that really calls for hard tuning I lean towards wanting it to feel invisible / natural. Im realizing more what parts of the note actually need to be more 'on' and which can be more 'off' or just left alone. That and letting notes naturally drift to become more sharp as they tail off. If I'm too heavy handed it starts to feel lifeless to me. I'm also appreciating more the nuance of how one might approach different genres or styles with melodyne. Its humbling how powerful the program really is.

There've been a few moments with the attack speed tool that have felt like magic curing some subtleties of the performances that bug me, but I don't feel super confident that I have a grasp on that one yet. I've been working in standalone and importing a REF mix. For some reason I feel more confident dealing with esses in protools with RX or clip gain than I do melodyne idk why. Some frustrations have been flipping back and forth between tracks when tuning multiple files feels real clunky. I might be missing something about how best to do that. I wish, like with RX monitor, you could hear the vocal through your mix chain when tuning (is that possible?). Being able to rename exported files would be nice too like in RX.

author: Deleted User
content:
I had this one particular vocal session where I was fucking up and all my comments were messing with the artist’s flow. So about an hour or two into the session, I got real with the artist and said “I feel like I’m being too much of a control-freak and my comments seem to be distracting you. Why don’t we take a break? When we come back, let’s forget about everything I mentioned earlier and see how things come out when you express freely. I have a feeling that it’s gonna turn out way better. I’m sorry, I think I got it your way” 

then after the break, the artist started nailing the takes. Not in the exact way I imagined, but in the best possible way that we were capable of THAT DAY. 

Since then, I decided to let go of control a bit more and let the artists do their thing as much as I can. I started developing ears for hearing what artists can work on before the session to get a better recording to my best of ability (if I get to know them before the sesh). I would only mention the simple things that can be improved with small adjustments short-term. That way the session can be more experimental and wild as opposed to fault-finding.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I really like the range function. There’s something in the way that it reacts that I just can’t get ProMB to sound the same. (And I’ve tried). 

I tend to be doing pretty wide, easy, just a few DB moves with it. The sharp resonant notches I used to use have been MOSTLY replaced by eq or soothe. 

You don’t have to use all the bands. Less is more. 

The whole reason I c6 over c4 is the side chain feature, where I’ll just have it last on say the guitar bus, triggered by the vocal, just ducking enough space to make the vocal a bit more intelligible. Bit like the song mixing itself. 
I find I’m not using c6 a ton on the actual track, it’s always side chained. 

C4 is more on the track itself. Really handy to focus a chunk of the audio. You can control the range of say 2-5k, and then move the entire volume of that up and down as it only dances with 5db of itself. Useful.

Not sure if I’ve mixed a song where the c4 isn’t on the drum bus somewhere.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I know I’m the other matt but when I’m doing that technique I’m usually just working on a single cycle of the waveform. It’s tedious, but to me it’s totally transparent, and I’m rarely cross fading because it just doesn’t need it at that microscopic level. But I have no doubt that the better matt is right about it on bigger sections. 

When I do it in protools (the slightly larger sections) I’ve found you can nudge one of the two things you’re cross fading sample by sample and you’ll watch the over lapping waveforms kind of level out at a specific spot where it’s the most transparent sounding fade. 

A majority of time I find if you’ve cut up your blobs properly in melodyne, melodyne works just fine, but on the really really delicate shit I’ll do the single cycle wave form duplication. 

(I hope this makes sense, I’m hurtling through the air at 35000 feet on a not insignificant amount of Xanax)

author: Jack
content:
My immediate spitballed thoughts are: 

— Percussion can be less invasive than harmonic additions (but also sometimes way more invasive) 

— Doubling vocal/other melodies with different instrumentation in unison rather than something contrapuntal  

— Additions that live harmonically below the vocal melody tend to be less attention grabbing, lowpass also tends to psychologically push them back 

— There’s a clip where @oaklandmatt mentioned recording his Juno’s noise separately to mix in at will which opened my eyes to how bizarrely ‘functional’ just ambience can be. Sometimes mixing in some field recording can work wonders. 

— Processing verb/delay sends can bring some more prominence to what’s already there

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another example:

On Brett’s last record, he did a demo with a co-writer of a song I loved. he tracked vocals with me, and I suggested the track needed a Mayer style guitar solo, so I played it. When Dann Huff heard it he told Brett “we’ll just upgrade Noah’s track to Master Scale. It’s not gonna get any better than that.”

When they went into the studio, they ended up taking the Mayer idea all the way, and the whole thing kinda went Country “Don’t Trust Myself.” They couldn’t do a Mayer solo on top of a Mayer vibe cause it would go from inspired by to straight derivative. 

My solo didn’t make the record, and I didn’t get any production credit. But the guy who did the demo did. I did get some BGVs on it and paid accordingly. All that felt right to me.

author: Ed Sokolowski
content:
I think the whole -18dBFS thing gets banded around in so many different ways. In theory, it should be that a 4dBu sine wave=-18dBFS=0VU. And a vocal (or anything else) that’s hovering around 0VU will likely have its peaks much higher than -18dBFS. -18dBFS (or whatever other calibration standard) is referring to an average level/constant voltage so that there is enough headroom to capture peaks without clipping. Many converters don’t use -18dBFS=4dBu (or 0dBFS=22dBu) though, they all vary and lots are adjustable.

TLDR is as long as you aren’t clipping, you’re good.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Some ideas:

- cut out lots of stuff for a bar or less before chorus
- stereo field narrow -> wide 
- frequency balance more mid centric -> full spectrum
- less subdivisions -> more subdivisions
- less legato instruments filling dead space -> more
- lower actual level -> higher (like @Bryan DiMaio said, cleverly and smartly)
- Some kind of "hit"/stab/cymbal starting chorus
- Tempo automation sometimes, slower or faster into chorus can work

All that said, my fav is when the vocal/melody automatically lifts the energy and the rest derives from that

author: Deleted User
content:
usually saw/buzz basses can’t have much perceived subs without filtering because of the amount of upper harmonics. with shorter saw bass- I usually tend to favor the upper area for punch and get the low subs from kick and if I need lengths in the lows I double it with a sub or electric bass and not use the sub from the saw bass. on saw bass with longer sustain- I like to do band pass filtering (take out subs and filter out the sizzlely highs) and use a separate sub bass in the middle and use saw bass that spreads out on the sides. 

I wouldn’t do significant boost lows on saw bass, I find it just messes with the character of the sound too much

author: ehutton21
content:
Whenever I get left field projects, I always talk with the artist about what they ideally want and then I kind of just try a couple versions where I’m doing big changes. 

If it’s poorly recorded, I’ve found success on finding a deliberate style for the one “poor sounding” element in a song—be it vocals, drums etc and then stylizing the elements around them. If the drums sound meh, blow em up—make ‘em loud, distort, double/warp, chop.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yes! Honestly when you stack the fuck outta airy vocals you can make them a LOT darker than you would a single vocal. All the air sums pretty violently. Also eq individual tracks AND busses. Once you get an idea of how her particular voice stacks, you can eq on the way in and save some time. 
3rdly, getting the performance as close to perfect as you can instead of tuning or auto-aligning will do a lot for the stereo field and vitality of the overall sound. 

If you’re just talking about the lead vocal, Multiband or Dyanmic Eq is your friend, but absolutely CRUSH that LV with something that has inherent low end saturation like Devil Loc (at like a 2) or a UAD 175-B. That’ll help balance the overall eq of the vocal better than just an additive eq/saturation. 

I know that’s a lot but hopefully that’s helpful!

author: wilhelmjosephk
content: I love this sound and a lot of the other stuff that Jockstrap's come up with, and while this is a bit of a non-answer, I think the key is that these sounds are easier to arrive at than they are to aim for. I think a lot of what Taylor Skye is doing is taking sounds and then warping them/distorting them to shit using all of the "wrong" methods, and then just judging what comes out and deciding if it should be kept. I think there's a good hint of this in the lead sound at the start, where it's really out of rhythm and grainy, some notes seem to sort of "break" which reminds me of the results you get when you try to formant shift a verbed-out or polyphonic sound with little alterboy, or even abusing izotope RX on something that doesn't really need it (also, the RX de-reverb can do wild things to a sound you've put reverb on higher in the chain). Logic, which is what he uses, also has a lesser known formant shift that you can only get to by turning on flex pitch then adjusting in the side info bar, which can really take sounds into space. I haven't done this with melodyne, but I imagine there are some similar features.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! Massive was my go-to for years prior to Massive X.

The biggest change for me is that the raw oscillators sound far better. The original Massive had a lot of aliasing that could make it sound hazy and flat. Switching over to Massive X it is crystal clear and even buzzy saw waves feel warm, pure, and tactile.

It has extremely flexible modulation capabilities that I find to be very musical as well as some very comprehensive ADSHR envelopes. It also has four different keyboard tracking curves that you can assign and tweak, which is very important when fine-tuning your patch to make sure that it sounds even across the entire range of keys.

It has a lot of musical sounding filters that can inject a ton of vibe, or be completely neutral. The *noise* section is robust and very flexible. I use it a lot.

Finally, it has a great-sounding set of internal effects (delay, chorus, saturation, verb, etc) that can be placed anywhere inside of the routing diagram. It's always a bummer when the on-board effects aren't very inspiring. But NI has a strong catalog of well-designed dsp to draw on and integrate into their products, so it's turned out great.

Overall, it's a very robust and well-rounded synthesizer that also does a lot of things extremely well. It can be super clean (like Serum) but also get very dirty, which I appreciate in a synth.

The only thing I don't like is that the preset browser kind of sucks. I prefer the original Massive's browser. NI is well aware and they have been overhauling it and slowly adding new features, so I trust in time this will be made better.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think people underestimate how much a well-designed synth patch is it's own instrument. It can have it's own feel, idiosyncrasies, and sweet spots. Something that takes time to learn and adjust your playing to.

I don't use a lot of different patches. I probably have a 3-4 patches that I've built and I am slowly refining, tuning ranges, and adding features over time.

author: Adam Thein
content:
It's really simple in Live (and I'm sure there's equivalent warp modes in other daws) - use the Repitch Warp mode, move the tempo down til you are slightly slower (the track will play back at a lower pitch), record at that new key and tempo, and warp it back up (Repitch mode on whatever you recorded).  The formants and the pitch and the tempo will all move together and playback smoothly.

I think @Ross Fortune has mentioned this before but the iOS app MusicMath has a handy tool to input the BPM and how many semitones you want to transpose and it'll kick out the correct new BPM to get the transposition you want.

The MIDI track was just a plain sine wave synth, but you could also get some cool gated effects by using different inputs

author: NoahNeedleman
LAPhill
content:
Oooh I have a theory here, about cultural values. Audiences in the 1800s, for instance, could go to a symphonic concert and recognize sonata form, key centers, etc. There was an appreciation for the form of the music and the virtuosity of the player first and foremost. Acknowledgement of skill. Making things seem effortless was the ideal.

Contemporary listeners seem to connect more with the struggle. They want to hear the grit in the vocal, the player at the edge of their ability (whatever it may be) holding on for dear life. The mix at the edge of distortion. In that breaking point, there is a lot of beauty and emotion that would have traditionally been considered bad form. Uncouth, even!

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I hand edit with audiosuite AT graphical mode if I want it not to sound tuned. There is no close second tuning software for this purpose. It is easily the best for transparent tuning.

Unfortunately it randomly does the following:
*reads notes in the wrong octave
*plays back notes in the wrong octave
*shaves off all the high end 
*adds a click to the beginning of the rendered file
*adds a weird glitch that sounds like a bad edit in the rendered file
*says it can't authorize the plugin

So I'm constantly shifting between classic and modern modes, and switching the input type which sometime corrects some of these things. Again, often seemingly at random.

author: Will Trotman
content:
In addition to the diamonds like Noah said, just root notes chugging away or playing 8th notes can be helpful and non invasive if chords or power chords feel too informative. Octaves can be a cool halfway point. A lot of songs seem to have room for the clean “dinky” sort of electric parts (sometimes slightly melodic or sometimes just hanging out on a single note).

If it’s a matter of filling space, something that helped me on a pop track the other day was making a second track for echoes of the lead vocal where you can low pass it pretty hard and delay / verb it out.

I often find myself introducing subtle sub basses later in the song, potentially doubling electric bass with synth bass, maybe layering snares to be fatter in later choruses. Then playing with some subtle percussion elements like triangle, clave, wood blocks, to differentiate later choruses.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll add two things here:

**1.** If a session relies on shared samples or IRs then both you and your partner should get in the habit of habitually doing a *Collect All and Save* before you close out the session. Every time.

This way the samples travel with the session and your partner does not have to go searching. **The assets should always be saved with the session.**

**2.** Move the date (YYMMDD) to the front of all file names, such as sessions and renders.

File names will look something like this:

260214 Track title
260214 Track title v2
260215 Track title (vocal editing)
260216 NEW track title (160 bpm)

This way your assets are always filed chronologically and there is no question which version is the most recent version. It's always at the end of the list.

(It’s all super project dependant) If I’m both producing and tracking I’ll often just get the production to a point where it’s good to write to and simple enough to have ideas flow. Then throw it into a vocal tracking session and get the demo vocals and get the song written and record a few too many parts. Then produce the song around the song and vocals. Usually I’ll have beat and vocals separate, but sometimes it makes more sense to have in the same session. Depends on the song. But I always track over a 2 track. Because it takes a lot of risk out of having some random synth or plug-in chain from the production mess up the session while trying to get good takes with the artist.(total buzzkill if you have to restart a session when the vocalist is in the zone) 
But again soooooo project dependant. Depends on how the artist likes to work, time line, amount of sessions that are possible to have together and so on. Sometimes you’ll only have one day with an artist, and if you are also producing, leave all the cool production tricks til later and get the best vocals you can get.

IME it depends a lot on who the players are. There are certain people I would call to play parts more or less as written, and others whose whole vibe is based off of experimentation. Both have their place for sure.

One thing you keyed in on that is really crucial is the "space" you ask them to fill. Even something as simple as "ad lib between vocal lines" tells the player a lot about where they need to fit in, while still giving them a lot of freedom to bring their thing to the production. 

Certainly a place for all of these approaches, and the more you know and trust the musicians around you, the easier it becomes to envision where it might go (and leave room for pleasant surprises).

author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh, just one more thing. I find it very helpful to practice making patches by trying to emulate a given instrument's expression. I'm primarily thinking about note articulation, here. Modeling these behaviors is a good way to start thinking musically with a synthesizer.

So if I'm going for a "horn" instrument I want a patch that can do attack-y stabs, but also fade into notes and have complete dynamic control. It should also have some sort of brightness feature that I can open up at will, like blowing harder into some brass.

If I'm emulating a voice there's going to be a big emphasis on legato playing and fluidity, with some very expressive pitch control for bends and vibrato. Maybe some form of subtle formant control to shade the notes like a singer would with different vowel sounds.

An organ patch is going to be a dead simple note-on/note-off volume envelope with the expression coming from the addition or subtraction of different oscillators.

And some patches are just going to be gangly chaotic messes that you do your best to wrangle. Something with a lot of chaos and feedback and squealing. You can't control it, but you just strap in.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. And there's a way to convey all of this without being hamfisted about it. 

Believe you me, I *hate* the feeling that I'm being pitched to. If I get a whiff of it without having asked for it I have an allergic reaction.

A lot of people don't know what they don't know. They don't understand how much effort goes into tuning or finessing a vocal performance. From their perspective they laid down a great one and when the final comp shows up sounding amazing they might assume that all you did was comp a few takes, EQ, add some compression and *voila*. They don't know about the hours and hours you spent getting it all just-so, listening, and then adjusting again. Not to mention your years of hard-won judgement that allow you to know when it's the correct move. That's all invisible to the client.

Of course, pros will likely know all of this because they've had the experience enough times. They're less likely to challenge you on why your all-in fee is at such a level.

author: LAPhill
content:
Any thoughts on how to convey value, given these dynamics then? I doubt many people here would think that going into detail about the behind-the-scenes process is the answer. To the client/artist, the work either resonates or it doesn't, elevates or not. And that's how it should be. Helping people zoom out and focus on the FEEL difference that's been made seems like a start, but as we all know, it can be hard to see the forest for the trees. And if the artist is hyper-focused on how much reverb is on the vocal, they're losing the context of WHY the decision was made, and how it feels as a whole. 

I don't have answers here, but I'm curious of other's thoughts.

author: austenballard
content:
I didn't doubt you were right,  I wanted to measure it to see it for myself and record the process and results for anyone else who might be curious.

I'm also glad I tested it because not only is tuning different between the different versions, like you said, but detection is different as well! And this is not disclosed at all by Celemony in the Melodyne documentation, unless you infer it from that bit in the manual I screenshotted yesterday.

I think in general it's important to rigorously test our tools when we suspect or observe that they're not working as they should. The likes of GS and Vi-Control are full of people talking about issues but never actually testing them. We can do better here, especially when testing, like you did with Auto-Tune, leads to an opportunity to put queries and complaints to the manufacturers themselves.

1) Different tunings, Having clean vs processed, peaking at below -6, good velocity layers, round robin is good but not really necessary for me, I personally don’t need all mics separate but would like to have a separate room sample and the mixed sample as well.

2) Yes please!! I hate it when samples peak at 0. I actually turn all of them down when I put them into a sampler to make it peak at -8 to -12

3) small snippets of hihats or snare ghost notes and some tom loops. I’d probably prefer them mixed only

4) for kits I think it is important. Round robin and velocity layers, and if you are doing rooms or separate mics having a kit makes an instantly playable and tweakable kit.

5) I’m not sure. Anything between 44.1/16 and 48/24 should be fine! Anything beyond might be too much

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Not just the performance, it’s the voice itself. Some singers take to tuning really well, some not as much. 
BUT, the voice modulation tool in Melodyne can be used to pretty good effect here.

author: Adam Thein
content:
This is probably repeat info but I like to split the audio between transients manually then use the Shift+Option+Command (on mac) combo and click drag the audio to slip the audio within the clip, then slice the next transient and you can get into a flow pretty fast and manually slice up an entire take pretty quickly.  Multimic sources like drums I do the same thing but with the "Link Tracks" option.  Can usually fly through a full song pretty quickly.

Especially for acoustic guitars, drums, and vocals that are super sensitive to warping this is usually my method in Ableton.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yes. This is huge. As you lengthen the pre-delay it simultaneously makes the back wall of your mix sound farther away *and* makes your source (let's say a lead vocal) sound closer to the listener. It's the separation and contrast between the two elements that gives this definition.

On the other hand, using a short pre-delay time and "gluing" the verb to the source can make the source sink backwards into the mix as you balance your fader level and the dry/wet level.

author: Maxim
content:
Sounds like you’re looking for density without it being cluttered or overproduced. 

Usually “noise” (not literally but parts of the groove that you mainly feel but don’t make out specifically like you would a kick and snare or hi hat) serves this purpose for me. Elements which if muted would leave you feeling like something is missing but you can’t necessarily make them out when in. 

I guess this could be anything from a few percussion loops (maybe panned/verb with no pre-delay or less high end to place them at the back of the mix) to a subtle vocal or foley sample playing one note throughout the groove. 

Layering to me is part of this but my intent with it is usually to create a sound or get more out of an element (like layering the attack of a snap with a clap for a different transient / texture). But this doesn’t always add to “fullness” in my mind. It just makes one element better or more interesting. 

Maybe start with the loops and foley. Splice Bridge makes testing things really easy too.

author: delwin
content:
I do this a lot!

In Ableton, you have soooo many options. Most often I put the sample on an Ableton Simpler and am able to slice / pitch / etc really fluidly — record that, and then edit by hand. This is my workflow for 90% of vocal chops. If it’s really simple I’ll do it by hand but I find I get more musical results if I can “play” the chop. 

There’s also Buffer Shuffler and Beat Repeat in Ableton which can be fun and unpredictable. 

The Glitch Machines plugins are also really nice if you’re going for something a bit crazy (two of them are free and very good). I don’t fully understand them yet so I just throw them on when I want something wacky to happen. 

And I’ll also second stutter edit — very fun for “playing” chops live too, and editing presets isn’t too hard either.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not Melodyne, but AutoTune graphic mode allows you to edit audio on the timeline after it’s been transferred into the plug. Handy if you spot a click or a mouth noise you missed.

In Pitch & Time mode it behaves like melodyne in that you can’t edit the audio on the timeline, but the time stretching inside the plug is the smoothest I’ve heard for vocals (I don’t use melodyne so that could be just as good)

author: ehutton21
content:
Vocalign is really essential to my work flow because of how many harmonies i get from clients & collaborators. I also create doubles with it a lot & use melodyne/alterboy to enhance the texture. 

As far as editing groove/timing, that’s hard cause I always cut that stuff until it feels right. Most of the time I’m gettin tracks where the artist or the producer or whoever (lots of times it’s the same person) has already agonized over the timing and cut it up so it’s solid. I’m mindful of words where the first syllable is cacophony or plosive-based (k, t, d) when it comes to sounds that hit on the quarter note (esp with snares). I usually let those sounds start just before the transient and end so that vowel is starting right on the note, depending on how it’s quantized if that makes sense. 

Feel like groove editing gets a weird wrap but i here songs where the timing could have used aligning after the amount of compression that got applied.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. 

So I should clarify a little bit. These 3-4 patches aren't static sounds that I never change. Think of them more like initialized synth templates with pre-determined routings and modulation that I can start with and then diverge from. I still use other people's presets, but using these templates can save me a good 15 minutes every time that I want to build a new patch and don't want to start all the way from scratch. They come with a lot of built-in expression.

On most of these I've got a lot of the keyboard tracking already tuned so that a bright patch doesn't get too harsh as I go up in register or it doesn't get too flabby and lose definition in the low-end.

I've got one patch set up for very expressive pitch modulation. Lots of big sweeps and bends in the attack/release envelope phases. Think wonky Neptunes-type sounds or two-octave dive bombs. Stuff like that.

One patch is set for expressive filter and amplitude modulation. Wobbles, envelope modulations, and such. It's my go-to if I'm trying to play with some "brassy" dynamics.

One is a legato mono patch for very fluid vocal-like playing. A big emphasis on note articulation and variation. I think of it as a solo instrument.

The final one is (you called it) A nice poly synth. Think James Blake on a Prophet. Pretty standard stuff, but once again it's got keyboard tracking that's tuned up so that the patch feels rich across the entire range.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I haven't done a deep-dive on *Autotune Real Time*'s algorithm, but my guess is that it would be a delay-line style pitch shifter because of it's need to process in real time.

Those types of pitch shifters are just fancy arrays of that pitch-rising/pitch-falling effect that you can get on a high-feedback delay unit by modulating the delay time. So it follows that they're going to have to delay the signal by *a little bit* in order to allow some audio into the buffer.

author: austenballard
content:
So I was digging through the Discord for wisdom on comping/tidying/timing/tuning vocals and seems like there's some debate on whether one should time first or tune first. 

I like to time first, because:

- AFAIK time-stretching tends to emphasize tuning artifacts, while tuning can actually mask timing artifacts depending on how drastic the timing was.

- I'm often comping doubles from unused lead takes, and then doing a combination of Revoice and editing by hand to line them up, along with harmonies. I find this makes tuning easier, especially when to lining up a slide or melisma.

HOWEVER

- I could be mistaken/misinformed about the first point. I think the amount of artifacts also depends heavily on what DAW/algorithm was used for time-stretching, if it was done at all.

- Tuning can mess with timing. We all saw the AT conversation a few days ago, and Matt Beckley pointed out in a post a while back that Melodyne can also make timing a little wonky sometimes.

OTHER CONSIDERATIONS

- Is this just one of those 'it depends' situations?

- You can do both timing and tuning in Melodyne, although (to me) it feels a little more artifacty and a lot more time-consuming than working by hand and applying stretching, etc. as needed.

@BatMeckley @NoahNeedleman I feel like you two probably have the most expertise here - advice greatly appreciated.

author: JakeTB
content:
Method: Recorded vocal at 192kHz into Pro Tools. Exported via Shift+CMD+K at 192kHz and again at 48kHz. Vocals were both imported into Melodyne application in monophonic mode. Administered time stretching (both lengthened and shortened) via the time tool. Also administered pitch shifting via pitch tool and checked detection of tuning via correct pitch macro. After exporting these, they were reimported to see if detection had changed.

Objective Results:
-Upon import, vocal tempo detection was different. (One detected in 5/4, the other in 3/4, at drastically different tempos).
-For short notes, when using the time tool to stretch, there were audible differences in results.
-For long notes, when using the time tool to shorten, there was significantly less audible difference (subjectively: no difference)
-For pitch detection, the algorithm detected pitch differently both audibly and visually.

Subjective Opinions:
-Time stretching yielded reduced artifacts in extreme settings when done at 192kHz. It did not eliminate all artifacts, but did reduce them.
-When time stretching in a more nuanced way, the differences in artifacts were negligible.
-When adjusting pitch manually, there was no audible difference in the quality of the pitch shifting at different sample rates. (For this test, everything was shifted up half an octave before any adjustments made)
-When detecting pitch, both behaved quite differently. This was partially due to detection of select blobs being different at either sample rate. (This was most surprising to me of all the results)
-When blobs were adjusted to match as closely as possible by hand, the tuning seemed to behave identically, including locations and levels of artifacts. (My gut says they “felt” different but that is most likely either placebo or the slight differences in true blob locations)

author: Ross Fortune
content:
1) what are the top 5 most important things for you in purchasing a drum sample pack ?


I never purchase drum sample packs - not since having Splice. I do like a clear identity in a pack though - for instance, The Kount's sample pack has all those lo-fi/saturated kicks and snares, wonky grooves and crusty hi hats etc that sit very much in his genre, so if I'm reaching for that sound, I know exactly where to go. 

I don't know your drummer or his band, but I'd wonder what distinctive character you could capture in your pack? So that I know exactly where to go when I want "that" sound in a writing session instant. 


2) I’m always annoyed that all samples are 0.0db normalized and I always have to turned them way down to keep my gain staging coherent, would I be crazy to have them peak at -8 ? Would people automatically hate it ? 

I produce largely in Ableton now, and when you drop a sample in the drum rack, the instance of Simpler it creates defaults to -12dB. With the velocity:volume dial at default (45%), this causes a 0dB sample to play back at -6dB when velocity=100 (the default). My template has all mixer faders (including a basic drum rack + instance of Drum Buss) trimmed to -9dB (similar to my mix gain staging strategy I detailed previously), allowing me to mash stuff up if needed, and still have headroom to not have to max out vocals when it comes to cutting them. What I'm saying in a roundabout way is... I've already made allowances for 0dB samples, so I don't care - but you probably should, because if you're selling on Splice, they could sound dwarfed against the next pack.

Ah, was just about to chime in with smearing transition with a reverb perhaps.

Related sidenote, there’s a vocal run in the <bridge> edit: actually second pre chorus of Want To Want Me by Jason Derulo that’s Frankensteined together in a way that’s very apparent to me now, but wasn’t when I first heard the song. Like @NoahNeedleman and others said, in those circumstances it’s usually fuck aroundery with fade lengths and shapes, sometimes nudging either half to make it transition in a noticeable but potentially musically appropriate way (maybe around a consonant if there is one, or at a melisma point in a run or whatever)

author: Deleted User
content:
Reverb throw might be a better choice than a revealing crossfade. Especially it being a very emotionally charged part. I've spent about 4 hours on this outro trying to figure out how to move the fades around to make it work but this one particular phrase was not coming together and there weren't other usable takes either. 

What I've done so far is I added a little decresc and cresc that wasn't there before, which made it more natural and was still musically appropriate. And did some audio suite EQ moves to match the formant as best as I can between the two takes. and then messed around with clip gain automation and fade points and shapes to see if I can get them to connect seamlessly. 

I could probably do it better next year, but this needs to be done now - so I think I'm just gonna go ahead and put on a reverb throw haha:kekcry:

author: Slow Hand
content:
Good points. Even if the gap between adoption of certain traditions is still wide, do you think we'll see that divide start to narrow more quickly now that we live in an era of wider and more immediate contact with other cultures? It feels like it's trending in that direction.

You're right about tonal systems. They're foundational properties that aren't so easily assimilated because of differences in tool set and cultural upbringing, so it's understandable that Western creators (as an example) don't have the means to implement them right as quickly.

That said, microtonal Western music (while still a niche) has a community of adopters who are building tools to open those doors to people who are interested in engaging with it. Ableton recently packaged it's DAW with the means to implement custom-tunings. Logic has had a version of this for quite some time. It's baby steps, sure, but I think it's slowly trending in a direction that's giving people the means to participate with one another.

author: Slow Hand
content: I should also clarify that I don't expect Top 40 music to be integrating Ethiopian tunings any time soon. But the groundwork is being laid and maybe in a few generations a lot of us will be speaking that dialect too.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think the band Secret Chiefs 3 is a good glimpse at what a truly pan-musical approach could be like. Though they are far from pop music. 

They're drawing on a wide variety of musical systems: Western diatonicism, Messiaen-ic (lol) scales, Azerbaijani mugham, Afghani traditionals, Italian avant-garde film score, surf rock, and so on.

They integrate a lot of different tuning systems and rhythmic approaches into their compositions. Trey Spruance has said on a few occasions that their seemingly arabic-sounding music would sound just as foreign to an arab musician as it would to an American listener. They embody a real ethos to fuse as much of these musics together.

https://open.spotify.com/track/2qHkwrDOfg291jbrQbb91z?si=dd5397e501784b3a

author: Skyler Young
content: The tone shift effect is something that I was thinking about for a long time - it manipulates which samples you access for each note played. For example you shift it +12 and play C1 it will take the sample from C0 and play it at double speed - changing the character of the sound sometimes drastically. If the range knob is at 50% and shift is at 0 and you play C0 it will use the sample from G0 (because it’s 50% the distance from C0) and if you play C2 it will use the sample from G1 - also has interesting effects on the sound. I still haven’t figured out the best way of explaining this function but I find it really usable and I’ve never seen sometime implement it before.

author: Marshall
content: A lot of singers (if not most tbh)  train their voices to sounded way different singing than they do speaking (pitch, tone, formant, etc)....They are basically "acting" vocally lol. Meanwhile, some singers do just sing with the voice they were given. I feel like the performance of "putting on" a voice that isn't your own is tough to capture on command. whereas, playing guitar is just athletic

author: Marshall
content: muscle memory with guitar is way more reliable than muscle memory in singing.....with guitar, your fingers just need to move fast enough and apply enough pressure on the strings and the instrument produces the tone for you. With vocals, you have to have every single muscle/vocal flap/space in the throat/sinus congestion level/etc perfect to produce a certain tone

author: Slow Hand
content:
Vocoders are finicky, temperamental, and need a sweet spot to work their best. This one is always dialed in perfectly and retains great vocal articulation.

I suppose the one downside is that you can't change the underlying synth patch that's used as the carrier signal. But unless you're really opinionated about what you want, then it's going to be the right choice 95% of the time.

author: Rob Domos
content: To be embarrassingly transparent, a lot of times I think a note is late by listening and then after looking find out it was early. Things just feel in time or out. Also, a lot of things that have loose rhythm in a way that people tend to love often bother me and sound out of time to me. Jay-Z is a perfect example of this. I spent years thinking his rhythm was terrible before I realized he was doing a shuffle time feel where the amount his vocal is off from the snare creates the shuffle. I just didn’t pick up on that for like… 15 years? And just wondered why nobody else was bothered him being “out of time”. Kind of like when people with an undeveloped sense of harmony think of jazz as simply being an excuse for allowing wrong notes. That’s how I hear people that are famous for stretching rhythm

content:
2. Vocal chops 

Listen down to the main vocal and whatever really jumps out ….a little melody run or phrase ….chop up and replay on the keyboard
Think of your vocal chops as a keys part . Play the chops backwards , re form a new melody , reverse etc . These chops are now a rythmic device

Bass has to be the hook playing off the vocal chop 

In logic the FM synth and I think it’s ES1 all have the house bass and organs and pianos (will check the modules and edit this if in correct )

author: Deleted User
content:
Art is subjective, so there’s actually no “better” — This is something I need to remind myself of more. The amount of times that I showed something that I thought was good and was rejected, and the times I showed something I hated and got good reactions from  people. You really never know! 

I’ve been doing more writing sessions these days (once or twice a week or so), and I’m really falling in love with this because I can get out of my own head and look around to get a sense of whether an idea is working or not outside of my own opinions

Speaking of the relentless will to finish: would it be a producer’s job to stay on top of getting others in team to get their parts done? If I’ve done my part already and completed it, do I keep bothering them to get their parts done? (lyrics etc) 

I read your reply to someone asking about writing sessions, and you said your biggest goal is to get the vocals from the first spark of inspiration on that same day. I’ve had sessions where I get a basic bone of ideas with beat done, and top line is done but the lyrics are recorded in Gibberish and stream of consciousness. I would return, complete the arrangement on my own - send it back, they said they fuck with it and tells me they will finish the lyrics. How long do I wait, do I follow up at all, or do I just move on and keep making more? I don’t want to overstep or rush people (and.. I can’t get anyone to anything of course), but I also want to get the song done while I’m excited so I can keep moving forward. It’s hard to tell if I can even do about it or if I should just keep it moving and leave it be

author: louisvie
content:
Hi everyone, here's the situation for me right now 

Singer/Artist/Band Leader wants to release big single with video in 4 days to coincide with band's concert. (In important small venue in Paris, FR (hometown) friends will be there, big event he rightly envisions as a celebration for the new kick-ass song with the new kick-ass video.)

But, as close friend, band-in-question-member, sound guy and producer for the project, I think we should wait and take time to get very good vocals, while right now it feels like they're merely existing because song has to have vocals. Leaves no strong impression, or the impression that the performance lacks intention.

Band rocks (his guitar included), Harmonies and Gang Vocals are cool. 
Really the lead vocal is the only thing in the way of getting the song to be really good. 

On the one hand, I feel like his intuition for the release date (deadline is in 4 days) is good and could be very valuable for us.
On the other, I don't see why anyone would be truly excited for us if singer is mid.
(I know he's good deep down, he's given me chills when singing with no pressure, rn we're just lacking some of that magic.)

As the song is today, you wouldn't love to listen to the song on your way to work or school, enjoying it for what it is.

Anyway, right now I'm going to try and squeeze that magic out of him in the next following days when we can see each other.
As I'm typing this I also realize I should send him the instrumental and let him try shit alone. 

Maybe that's my answer.

author: louisvie
content: Currently de-essing the gang vocals. Making sure everything that's staying is done for real so I can focus on what's coming. Thank you so much Ruairi 💖 .

author: louisvie
content:
Thank you ! Did this today with him actually, 30 min after you sent this message I'm just seeing now, coincidentally.

 His brother went in to do metal vocals and him not being a singer, i put a ton of saturation using UAD FATSO live in Console which made his voice sound  larger than life, and then kept that on for the rest of the session

That allowed Leo the main singer to let his deep-ass voice resonate a lot in the lows. We got Verse 1 and the next part that way.

author: louisvie
content:
At some point I wanted him to try again and he felt like last take was good.

I used the dry vocals and did a similar but more controlled/blended in the rest of the instrumental sound. We let the previously over-treated vocal sit in a right place for the song and then the whole narrative of the performance just showed itself to us when playing all of that back. He said he felt happy about what we got, I did too, and keyboardist came to the studio at the end and was excited.

author: Eric Martin
content:
As an artist, I bounce my own stems and basically route things for what I want the show to be, sometimes all vocal FX and BGV’s get routed to one stem and the only thing I leave out is the actual lead that will be sung live, and then I’ll even bounce some drum FX out so that the live drums are supported with some of the FX that were used on the record.

LIVE production and STEMS for publishing are two different things from an artist perspective IMO

author: Slow Hand
content:
You may already be aware, but you can get very different textures by playing with the LFO shape on the tremolo. 

The bass is more of a sine/triangle shape while those vocal samples have harder edges, closer to a square wave. The square wave modulating volume at high rates will give you that "ripple" I think you may be hearing.

author: chris_donlin
content: Need some advice here! I've been working with an artist for a little over a year, have made 8 or 9 songs. We've had to retrack vocals for nearly every song because the performance just isn't quite there yet, but we always get it where we want it in the second session. I'm noticing a pattern of him sitting with the vocal and realizing he wants to sing it differently/better, but only feels this after we've tracked it once. Today was day 1 tracking vocals on a new song and it got to the point where i realized we were going to have to try again another day, I was felt fed up. I tried to discern what exactly i was frustrated at. Part of me was frustrated because it doesnt seem like he is ever truly prepared to track vocals, in the sense of being warmed up, having ideas of how he wants to sing, practicing ahead of time, singing random stuff in between takes, etc. The other part of me was frustrated with myself because im aware some of the responsibility falls on me as the producer/coach. I have no problem taking time to edit the vocal, i know it's part of the job, i enjoy it in fact haha - but is it fair to have certain expectations from him as the artist? I want to have a conversation with him about it but also be clear that i want to be better at my job too

author: EliHeathMusic
content: I've definitely experienced similar frustration in the past working with singers coming in unprepared. While there are always ways for us to improve as vocal producers and editors at the end of the day a really good comp of a bad performance isn't going to be as compelling as a good performance (maybe there are some exceptions). It sounds like you've been getting good performances the second time around so maybe that's all that matters but it might be worth having a conversation about how the artist can come in better prepared in the future (sharing practice strategies rather than scolding).

author: Josh
content: Honestly dude think of this like any other relationship you have. I stopped working with an artist I was close with because he never even wrote anything. He wanted me to do everything short of actually singing it, and then he was hard to get a half decent vocal out of. Because I felt like I was barely even making art at some point, I just stopped booking with him and he just hit me up last week saying he’s trying to write on his own again. Odd perspective, but I think I was too helpful and because he was insecure about his thoughts, ideas, and abilities, he ended up using me as a crutch, which is partly my fault. In the end, me moving on made him want to write again and I think that’s a super positive outcome considering I had a lot of negative feelings about it at the beginning of the year

author: Josh
content: Unsure of how helpful that spiel is considering the scenarios are different but I think our frustration came from a similar place. Everyone is different and maybe if you switch the standard to cutting the vocal on a different day then it will hold them more accountable.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Sure. I would start by muting everything except for the vocals (assuming vocals) and then re-introduce one by one the instrumental elements that might support the new angle you want to try.

In short, strip everything down that's non-essential, keep the parts that feel vital, and then re-build from there.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Other strategies for re-vamping the feel and arrangement:
1. Trying putting instruments in different registers (move the bass up/down an octave).
2. Play the song in a neutral form like only piano and vocals and listen for what it might suggest.
3. Substitute instruments (Ex: bowed bass instead of electric bass).
4. Try a different key.
5. Try half-time. Try double-time.

author: Juliette
content:
Hey guys! Hope everyone is doing well. I have a question— when setting up to record vocals, what levels do you generally let the volume peak at, and how does one work with dynamic performances? And a specific question: what should I keep the gain at on my interface?

This recent project has a very whisper-like vocal section that requires a little more gain, and then a lot of loud vocals that require less gain. 

This ends up leaving me having to either turn up the clip gain during mixing or turning up the bus, which leads to clipping. Or (something I really don’t like, because I tend to hear it a lot more) is adjusting the gain while tracking sections. There’s certainly a way to navigate this seamlessly, but I just don’t know it yet :stare:

author: Juliette
content:
Compressors are such a godsend. I did end up throwing a compressor on the whisper parts but the loud parts sound all out of whack.

I’ve also heard a couple people say they generally like to keep vocals at around -24dB. I feel like I can’t hear a thing around that range LOL

author: Deleted User
content:
I want to chime in here, I mostly agree with what the others said and as long as you don’t unintentionally clip all is well. But I think we can dig a bit deeper.

I like to work in a way during tracking/production that’s maybe a bit more old school with shooting for around -18dbFS on the average. It gives me a kind of fixed reference in my mind which gives me enough headroom for most dynamics. Now the important part is you have to turn up your monitoring/headphones volume to be adequately loud to work with those lower levels and then leave it there.That being said it might be necessary to bring down other pre existing tracks that are too loud.

Now since the volume of the monitoring/headphones stays the same during that tracking session you can use the gain of your preamp (or the output gain of the compressor, if you’re using one on the way in) to adjust the vocal or instrument so that for every part of the arrangement it feels right. So in a sense you are pre mixing during the recording, taking off some work down the line

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
My current approach to this involves a couple of principles, but this is the first that comes to mind:

1. If there’s a part with bg vocals performing different lines than the lead and there’s a lot going on, I try to have a spot earlier in the song where the exactly lines those BGs are performing have a moment to shine. For example, if there’s a low energy bridge where they can be clearly understood before the big hook where they can be perceived but not understood as well in the midst of so much. 

What this does is allow the listeners brain to process what’s being said with little effort, and then later when it’s in a tornado they can still perceive what it’s saying because they recognize it as something their brain already knows, so it’s not overwhelming for their brain to understand the words of multiple vocals going at once if there are layers of lines being performed (usually syncopated) around each other.

This applies to instruments as well, but instead of intelligibility of words I focus more on cutting frequencies so everything can fit well in the big moments. If they head a synth at full power in the intro and it comes back for a final hook, you can get away with cutting a lot of meat off of it and still have it be perceived as the same synth, without muddying the mix and also creating a nice ‘bringing the song full circle’ feeling - If the track calls for that.

I typed this off the cuff based in gut instinct so not standing by this message as full proof, but this all feels right to me as I explore what I have done for tracks, without having this much thought or words to it.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content: ^For adlibs or purely musical BGs, AKA layers that add more vibe and don’t need to be understood to get that across, I don’t usually care about this for those.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I haven't been as hands-on with all the non-autotune options as some, but my impression is that if you are simply using the auto mode feature of auto tune to get the sound, you can get some comparable results with things like Waves Tune, the Logic and Ableton native versions, etc. I'm sure there are differences, but you can at least get close.

If you're doing graphical tuning, Melodyne and Auto-tune are the standards. Logic has flex pitch but reliable people I've talked to say it doesn't have nearly the transparency as the other two. I also don't know anyone who uses it over Auto-tune or Melodyne.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
And not just for making things incrementally better, but for solving problems as well.

I recently was mixing a song with a young mixer who I gave my session to. I heard a very subtle low and thump after two particular downbeat and we could not figure out what it was. We solo'ed some groups and then I remembered that he had replicated my autotune settings on the bass guitar (he had a slightly different version). I know from lots of tuning experience that different modes will occasionally cause different types of artifacts. So we solo'ed the bass, switched from "modern" (his default) to "classic" and it was solved.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Of course there are limits to this technique too. The further you nudge any single edit, the more audible it will become. So if you want to lengthen or shorten a note A LOT, sometimes you will have to do multiple edits, or longer cross fades, or something else to achieve the most transparent result.

And one of the best in the biz is @BatMeckley who I'm sure has thoughts about when to hand edit vs using Melodyne's time adjuster.

I use autotune graphic and never use the timing feature so I can't help you there
